phrase.item: I am from Namadgut. It is a historic village.
We have the fortress of "Qaqa", which there's a long story about.
The person who built the fortress, his height was 40 meters.
The story is very interesting,
because it is hard to imagine a 40-meter person.
And I want others to know that in Wakhan, especially in Ishkashim, there are many historic places, and my hope is that more of our histories should be known,
more things read about us, and we also should know our history very well
and represent it to others.
The Pamir [region] is the territory of Tajikistan, but it is far enough from the center [Dushanbe].
[From Dushanbe] to Khorog is over 700 kilometers' distance, which is far.
There are many languages spoken in the Pamir. Seven languages are spoken in Pamir, and one of them is called Wakhi, which I am speaking now.
We have our own history, our traditional hat 'toqi', we have fortresses
and we have many things in our history that makes us differ from [other] people of Badakhshan, as well from people of Tajikistan.
The Wakhi language is also spoken in China, in a district there, and in Pakistan and Afghanistan.
Though our ways of talking may differ from each other, in general there is one Wakhi language.
In the future, we want to use the Wakhi language to write books and stories so that our language does not go extinct.
Of Nowruz [holiday], we have a lot of good memories, from childhood celebrating the Nowruz holiday. Nowruz is celebrated very differently in Pamir [compared to other places].
During Nowruz we all clean our houses, we "take off all the madness from inside" [i.e. forgive each others' mistakes].
We go to each other's houses, we forgive each other's sins.
There are many special games are played during Nowruz,
like the games "ulchak" and "qoliq".
I think, especially in the Pamir, the way Nowruz is celebrated is very interesting.
I think it is not wrong to say that the Pamir is "a homeland of Nawruz"
because Nowruz is still celebrated in all its details and in its proper sense, and no other holidays are celebrated the way [Nowruz] is.

If you look at the history, it has endured from the time of King Jamshed. In Pamir, whatever customs were left for us, we are still following in the way it is supposed to be, and the quality of our Nowruz celebration is high.
For each person, it is important to preserve his or her own language.
Because nowadays we are not able to speak our language purely.
We are mixing Russian as well English with it.
But I want there to be books, and I myself want to do research and write a book because it is one of the oldest languages and it should not go away.
No matter how much the world is developing, I want to keep the language pure and pass it on to my children -- I will teach them the Wakhi language.
Besides the Wakhi language, I also speak Shughni.
Rozhqala, a [Shughni] region within Badakhshan.
I have been there myself.
There are also many historic places [there], including a spring called 'Shoboron' and in Porshinev there is a spring called 'Nosiri Khusraw'.
The [Shughnis] also have many histories, they also have a beautiful language.

When you go and look, they also have many historic places, they also have many things that are worthy of praise. I wish there would be many writers in the Pamir who would write the entire history of the Pamir, and the history of each place separately, because we should be proud that we are Pamiris, as
we have such histories, a language, and a traditional hat. Whatever we have, we should represent those things and take care of them ourselves as well.
Rushan is also a nice place, and they have their own language. It is similar to Shughni language but they have their own dialect, which is different.
They also have nice people, because the holy Nasir Khusraw rated them highly too.
They also have many good places, but above all they have the most beautiful girls there, tall in height, so that all in all, the prettiest Pamiris are in Rushan.
